filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of nineteen separate prints designed and etched or engraved by Blake. The original works are housed in seven collections, including the Bodleian Library, British Museum, Robert N. Essick collection, Fitzwilliam Museum, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and National Gallery of Art, Washington. These separate prints join two others, Deaths Door and George Cumberland’s Card, and four series of prints, all previously published, to complete this important category of Blake's endeavors as a printmaker.
The new group of nineteen includes Blake’s first separate engraving, Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, executed while still an apprentice, and two of his masterpieces in mixed-method etching/engraving, the large Job and Ezekiel plates. The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder, Lucifer and the Pope in Hell, and Albion rose depict Blake's response to the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century. Blake printed these three, plus A Dream of Thiralatha and Joseph of Arimathea Preaching to the Inhabitants of Britain, in colors as part of his development of relief and planographic color printing in the mid-1790s. Other plates, ranging from The Approach of Doom to the Enoch lithograph and The Chaining of Orc, testify to Blake's lifelong experimentation with innovative graphic techniques. He produced Deaths Door and the Virgil Relief Etching as book illustrations but they were never published as such and exist only as unique, separate impressions. Introductions to each work offer information on medium, changes in state, dating, and subject. Blake’s Laocoön etching/engraving, sometimes considered a separate plate, is included among the Illuminated Books in the Archive.
Late in his career, c. 1820-25 or even extending into his final year, Blake returned to several of his earlier separate engravings, dramatically revising the interplay of darkness and light in their designs and adding new inscriptions on some plates that alter their meaning. These final states of Joseph of Arimathea among the Rocks of Albion, Job, Ezekiel, The Accusers, Albion rose, and Blake's largest and most ambitious print, Chaucers Canterbury Pilgrims, are included, along with extant earlier states. The publication of these and other multiple states and printings offer insights into Blake's development as a printmaker and changes in his thematic interests over several decades.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

desc.objtitle:
The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder,
Object 1 (Essick VIII)

objnote.p: This impression is in the third state of three. The plate was originally etched and engraved in 1793 and converted to this final state c. 1820-25. Fragments of the second state inscriptions are visible left of the signature below the design ("When") and right of the penultimate line below the design (the upper part of the "P" of "Page"). This impression is inscribed "F.K." (Frederick Keppel) in pen and ink lower left and "Designed and Engraved by William Blake" in pencil just above the bottom edge of the leaf. Neither inscription is by Blake and they are not shown here.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three male figures stand in a line with bodies turned to face right. The inscription above their heads identifies them as accusers, but the inscription below the design identifies them (reading from left to right?) as the "Accuser," the "Judge," and the "Executioner." The rightmost figure wears a shirt, breeches, and a laurel crown. He has short curly hair and turns his head to look to the left. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. His teeth are visible. Both arms are bent and crossed in front of his chest. With his right hand, he holds the haft of a sword, which is pointed upward. His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. In the inscription about the figures, he is identified as the accuser of murder. To his left, the middle figure turns his head to look forward. He has long hair, a mustache, and a beard; he also wears a spiky crown. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of fear. His teeth and tongue are visible. He raises both bent arms upward and clutches his head with both hands. The fingers of both hands appear to be curled inward. This figure wears a cloak that extends down behind his thighs. He may also wear a shirt and breeches(?). His legs are together with the right leg slightly in front of the left. In the inscription about the figures, he is identified as the accuser of adultery. The leftmost figure stands with his body facing right and head turned to look left and slightly down. He has short hair that stands on end, a mustache, and a beard. He wears a shirt composed of small circles, which may indicate chain mail, and pleated breeches or skirt(?). His costume suggests that of a Roman soldier. His right arm appears to be raised and extended behind the figure to his right. He may hold the spear pointed upward above the middle figure's head with his left hand (which is not visible). Only the right leg and foot of the leftmost figure are visible. In the inscription about the figures, he is identified as the accuser of theft. Lines below the feet of all three figures suggest sandals, but no straps are pictured. Three tall flames frame the group of figures at right and left. Behind the flames on both sides of the composition are two wooden vertical objects, which may be a door frame, as there appears to be a small horizontal step behind the figures' feet. The ground on which they stand may also be made of wood. Above their heads in the background is sky that may contain wispy clouds.
